options.description: Learn how to use the C driver to perform aggregation operations.

children.value: In this guide, you can learn how to use the C driver to perform

You can use aggregation operations to process data in your MongoDB collections and
return computed results. The MongoDB Aggregation framework, which is
part of the Query API, is modeled on the concept of a data processing
pipeline. Documents enter a pipeline that contains one or more stages,
and each stage transforms the documents to output a final aggregated result.

You can think of an aggregation operation as similar to a car factory. A car factory has
an assembly line, which contains assembly stations with specialized
tools to do specific jobs, like drills and welders. Raw parts enter the
factory, and then the assembly line transforms and assembles them into a
finished product.
You can use find operations to perform the following actions:
You can use aggregation operations to perform the following actions:
The following limitations apply when using aggregation operations:
Returned documents must not violate the

Pipeline stages have a memory limit of 100 megabytes by default. You can exceed this
limit by setting the

stage has a strict
memory limit of 100 megabytes and ignores the
The examples in this section use the

. To learn how to create a
free MongoDB Atlas cluster and load the sample datasets, see the
Build and Execute an Aggregation Pipeline
To perform an aggregation on the documents in a collection, pass a

structure
that represents the pipeline stages to the

This example outputs a count of the number of bakeries in each borough
of New York City. The following code creates an aggregation pipeline that contains the
following stages:

stage to filter for documents
in which the value of the

stage to group the matching
documents by the

field, producing a count of documents for each distinct
value of that field.

To view information about how MongoDB executes your operation, you can
run the the

operation on your pipeline. When MongoDB explains an
operation, it returns

and performance statistics. An execution
plan is a potential way MongoDB can complete an operation.
When you instruct MongoDB to explain an operation, it returns both the
plan MongoDB selected for the operation and any rejected execution plans.

The following code example runs the same aggregation shown in the preceding section, but
uses the
function to explain the operation details:
To view a full list of expression operators, see
To learn about assembling an aggregation pipeline and view examples, see
To learn more about creating pipeline stages, see
To learn more about explaining MongoDB operations, see

For more information about executing aggregation operations with the C driver,
see the following API documentation:

title.value: Build and Execute an Aggregation Pipeline

children.value:
The following compatibility table specifies the recommended version or versions
of the C driver for use with a specific version of MongoDB.
The first column lists the driver version.

MongoDB ensures compatibility between the MongoDB Server and the drivers
for three years after the server version's end of life (EOL) date. To learn
more about the MongoDB release and EOL dates, see

The Driver version will work with the MongoDB version, but not all
new MongoDB features are supported.
The Driver version is not tested with the MongoDB version.

The 1.18 driver does not support snapshot reads
on secondaries. For more information, see the
The driver does not support older versions of MongoDB.

The following compatibility table specifies the recommended version of the
MongoDB C Driver for use with a specific version of C.
The first column lists the driver version.
For more information on how to read the compatibility tables, see our guide on

This section includes version compatibility information about platforms and
toolchains that are supported by the C driver.
The following operating systems are continually tested with the C driver:

Versions 7.0, 7.1, 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3. RHEL derivatives
(for example, CentOS, Rocky Linux, or AlmaLinux) of the same release version are
supported. Fedora is also supported, but not continually tested.

Versions 16.04, 18.04, and 20.04. Subsequent minor releases
are also supported. Ubuntu 22.04 and newer is not yet tested. Ubuntu
derivatives based on supported Ubuntu versions are also supported.
Windows variants of the same generation are supported
The following compilers are continually tested with the C driver:

Versions 3.7, 3.8, and 6.0. Newer versions
are also supported, as well as the corresponding Apple Clang releases.

Versions 4.8, 5.4, 6.3, 7.5, 8.2, 8.3,
9.4, and 10.2. The MinGW-w64 GCC is also tested and supported.

Tested with MSVC 14.x (Visual Studio 2015) and 15.x (Visual Studio
2017). Newer MSVC versions are supported but not yet tested.
The following CPU architectures are continually tested with the C driver:
Tested on Linux, macOS, and Windows

Other platforms and toolchains are not tested, but we expect similar versions
of the preceding platforms to work. If you encounter a platform or toolchain that you
expect to work and find that it does not, please open an issue describing the
problem, or open a

Simple pull requests to fix unsupported platforms are welcome, but will be
considered on a case-by-case basis. The acceptance of a pull request to fix the
libraries on an unsupported platform does not imply full support of that
platform.

options.description: Learn how to use the C Driver to connect to MongoDB.

children.value:
This page contains code examples that show how to use the
C driver to connect your application to MongoDB by specifying
various settings.

To learn more about the connection options on this page, see the link
provided in each section.
To use a connection example from this page, copy the code example into the

or your own application.
Be sure to replace all placeholders in the code examples, such as
, with the relevant values for your MongoDB deployment.

You can use the following sample application to test the code examples on this
page. To use the sample application, perform the following steps:
Ensure you have the C driver installed.
Copy the following code and paste it into a new
Copy a code example from this page and paste it on the specified lines in the file.

The following sections describe how to connect to different targets,
such as a local instance of MongoDB or a cloud-hosted instance on Atlas.

The following code shows the connection string to connect to a local
instance of MongoDB:
To learn more about connecting to local deployments, see
in the Choose a Connection Target guide.

deployment hosted on Atlas:
To learn more about connecting to Atlas, see

in the
Choose a Connection Target guide.

The following code shows the connection string to connect to a
replica set:
To learn more about connecting to replica sets, see
in the Choose a Connection Target guide.

while enabling the TLS protocol.

To learn more about using TLS with the C driver,
see

connecting by using TLS:

options.keywords: connection string, URI, server, settings, client

children.value: In this guide, you can learn how to use a connection string and a

object
to connect to different types of MongoDB deployments.

To connect to a MongoDB deployment on Atlas, include the following elements
in your connection string:
The URL of your Atlas cluster
Then, pass your connection string to the

The following code shows how to use the C driver to connect to an Atlas cluster. The
code also uses the
function to specify a Stable API version.

When you connect to Atlas, we recommend using the Stable API client option to avoid
breaking changes when Atlas upgrades to a new version of MongoDB Server. To learn more
about the Stable API, see the
To connect to a local MongoDB deployment, use

as the hostname. By
default, the

process runs on port 27017, though you can customize this for
your deployment.

The following code shows how to use the C driver to connect to a local MongoDB
deployment:

To connect to a replica set, specify the hostnames (or IP addresses) and
port numbers of the replica-set members.

Instead of providing a full list of hosts in the replica set, you can
specify one or more of the hosts in the replica set and instruct the C driver to
perform automatic discovery to find the others. To instruct the driver to perform
automatic discovery, perform one of the following actions:
Specify the name of the replica set as the value of the
Specify more than one host in the replica set.

The following example uses a sample connection URI to connect to the MongoDB replica
set

.
When you connect to a replica set, the constructor returns immediately while the
client uses background threads to connect to the replica set.

object and immediately print the string representation
of its

attribute, the list might be empty while the client connects to
the replica-set members.

For more information about the objects and functions mentioned in this guide, see
the following API documentation:

options.keywords: connection string, URI, server, Atlas, settings, client

children.value: To connect to a MongoDB deployment, you need two things:

, which tells the C driver
which MongoDB deployment to connect to.

structure, which creates the connection to and performs
operations on the MongoDB deployment.
This guide shows you how to create a connection string and use a
A standard connection string includes the following components:

Required. A prefix that identifies this as a string in the
SRV connection format.

Optional. Authentication credentials. If you include these, the client
authenticates the user against the database specified in

Required. The host and optional port number where MongoDB is running. If you don't
include the port number, the driver uses the default port,

Optional. The authentication database to use if the
connection string includes

option. If you don't include
this component, the client authenticates the user against the

Optional. A query string that specifies connection-specific
options as
For more information about creating a connection string, see
To connect to a MongoDB deployment on Atlas, you must first create a client.
You can pass a connection URI as a string to the

function
to connect to a MongoDB instance:

You can set the Stable API version client option to avoid breaking changes when
you upgrade to a new server version.
To learn more about the Stable API feature, see the

The following code shows how you can specify the connection string and the
Stable API client option when connecting to a MongoDB deployment on Atlas
and verify that the connection is successful:
The Stable API feature requires MongoDB Server 5.0 or later.
In this guide, you can learn how to specify

compatibility when
connecting to a MongoDB deployment.

The Stable API feature forces the server to run operations with behaviors compatible
with the API version you specify. When you update either your driver or server,
the API version changes, which can change the way these operations behave.
Using the Stable API ensures consistent responses from the server and
provides long-term API stability for your application.

The following sections describe how you can enable and customize Stable API for
your MongoDB client. For more information about the Stable API, including a list of
the commands it supports, see
To enable the Stable API, perform the following steps:

object and specify a Stable API version. You must use
a Stable API version defined in the
Pass the client and the Stable API object to the
The following code example shows how to specify Stable API version 1:

Once you create a client instance with
a specified API version, all commands you run with the client use the specified
version. If you need to run commands using more than one version of the
Stable API, create a new client.
The following table describes the options of the

class. You can use these
options to customize the behavior of the Stable API.

, if you call a command that isn't part of
the declared API version, the driver raises an exception.

, if you call a command that is deprecated in the
declared API version, the driver raises an exception.
The following code example shows how you can set both options to

For more information about using the Stable API with the C driver, see the
following API documentation:

options.keywords: security, authentication, transport layer security, encrypt

children.value: In this guide, you can learn how to use the
protocol to secure your connection to a MongoDB deployment.
When you enable TLS for a connection, the C driver performs the following actions:
Uses TLS to connect to the MongoDB deployment
Ensures that the certificate certifies the deployment
To learn how to configure your MongoDB deployment for TLS, see the

A full description of TLS/SSL, PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) certificates, and
Certificate Authorities (CAs) is beyond the scope of this document. This page assumes prior
knowledge of TLS/SSL and access to valid certificates.

You can enable TLS on a connection to your MongoDB instance
in the following ways:
If your connection string includes the

modification, which specifies the
SRV connection format, TLS is enabled on your connection by default.
To learn more about the SRV connection format, see

When you connect to a MongoDB deployment with TLS enabled, the deployment will by default require the client to provide
a client certificate issued by a certificate authority, or an authority
trusted by the native certificate store in use on the server.
You can provide the client certificate in the following ways:
parameter in your connection string to a
file containing the root certificate chain
file containing the root certificate chain

If you don't specify a CA file when compiling against the Windows Native TLS library, the driver
will use the Windows Certificate Store. To learn more, see the
Native TLS Support on Windows (Secure Channel)

The MongoDB C Driver will automatically verify the validity of a server certificate issued
by the configured Certificate Authority. The driver also performs hostname validation and revocation checking.

To overwrite this behavior, it is possible to disable hostname validation, OCSP endpoint revocation checking,
all revocation checking, and allow invalid certificates.
This behavior is controlled using the

options. By default,
all are set to
It is not recommended to change these defaults, since you might expose your client to the following security risks:

By default, libmongoc will attempt to find a supported TLS library and enable TLS support. This is controlled
by the cmake flag
by default. This flag accepts the following values:
: Links to the system's native TLS library, or attempts to find OpenSSL. This is the default value.
: Links to OpenSSL (libssl). An optional install path may be specified with
(Deprecated): Links to LibreSSL's libtls. You can link to LibreSSL's compatible libssl by setting
: Links to Secure Channel, the native TLS library on Windows.
: Links to Secure Transport, the native TLS library on macOS.

The MongoDB C Driver uses OpenSSL on Linux and Unix platforms (besides macOS). Industry best practices
and some regulations require the use of TLS 1.1 or newer, which requires at least OpenSSL 1.0.1. Use the following command
to check your OpenSSL version:

Ensure your system's OpenSSL is a recent version (at least 1.0.1), or use the following command to install a recent version in a
non-system path and build against it:

When compiled against OpenSSL, the driver will attempt to load the system default certificate store, as configured by the
distribution. That can be overridden by setting the
URI option or with the fields

The Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) is fully supported
when using OpenSSL 1.0.1+. However, when a

revokes
the server's certificate, the certificate is considered revoked, even if the certificate has a valid stapled OCSP response.
For more information about OCSP, see
The MongoDB C Driver supports LibreSSL through the use of OpenSSL compatibility checks when configured to compile against
library when configured to build against

is not supported,
and will issue an error if used. Setting

The Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) is partially supported
with the following notes:
Connection will continue if a Must-Staple certificate is presented without a stapled response and the OCSP responder is down
Connection will not continue if the client receives a revoked response from an OCSP responder
For more information about OCSP, see
Native TLS Support on Windows (Secure Channel)
Native TLS Support on Windows (Secure Channel)

The MongoDB C Driver supports the Windows native TLS library (Secure Channel, or SChannel) and its native crypto library
(Cryptography API: Next Generation, or CNG).
When compiled against the Windows native libraries, the

is not supported
and will issue an error if used.
Encrypted PEM files, set by using the

URI option, are also not supported and will result in error when
attempting to load them.

is set, the driver will only allow server certificates issued by one or more authorities provided.
When no
is set, the driver will look up the Certificate Authority using the
certificate store to confirm the provided certificate.
, the driver will import the revocation list to the

The Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) is partially supported
with the following notes:
Connection will continue if a Must-Staple certificate is presented without a stapled response and the OCSP responder is down.
Connection will not continue if the client receives a revoked response from an OCSP responder.

revokes the server's certificate, the OCSP response
takes precedence. For example, if the server presents a certificate with a valid stapled OCSP response, the certificate is considered
valid even if the
For more information about OCSP, see
Native TLS Support on macOS / Darwin (Secure Transport)
Native TLS Support on macOS / Darwin (Secure Transport)

The MongoDB C Driver supports both the Darwin native TLS library and Common Crypto, its native crypto
library.
When compiled against Secure Transport, the

are not supported.
An error is issued if either are used.

is set, the driver will only allow server certificates issued by the authority (or authorities) provided.
When no
is set, the driver will use the Certificate Authorities in the unlocked keychains.
has no effect when compiling against secure transport.

The Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) is partially supported
with the following notes.
Connection will continue if a Must-Staple certificate is presented without a stapled response and the OCSP responder is down
Connection will not continue if the client receives a revoked response from an OCSP responder
For more information about OCSP, see

For more information about the objects and functions mentioned in this guide, see
the following API documentation:

title.value: Native TLS Support on Windows (Secure Channel)
Native TLS Support on macOS / Darwin (Secure Transport)

children.value:
In this guide, you can learn how to interact with MongoDB databases and
collections by using the C driver.
MongoDB organizes data into a hierarchy of the following levels:
: Top-level data structures in a MongoDB deployment that store collections.
: Groups of MongoDB documents. They are analogous to tables in relational databases.

: Units that store literal data such as string, numbers, dates, and other embedded documents.
For more information about document field types and structure, see the
guide in the MongoDB Server manual.
Access a database by using the
The following example accesses a database named
Access a collection by using the
The following example accesses a collection named

If the provided collection name does not already exist in the database,
MongoDB implicitly creates the collection when you first insert data
into it.

function to explicitly create a collection in a
MongoDB database.
The following example creates a collection called

You can specify collection options, such as maximum size and document
validation rules, by passing them inside a

structure as the third parameter
to the

function. For a full list of
optional parameters, see the
documentation in the MongoDB Server manual.
You can query for a list of collections in a database by calling the

function. The function returns a cursor containing all
collections in the database and their associated metadata.

function and iterates over
the cursor to print the results:
To query for only the names of the collections in the database, call the
For more information about iterating over a cursor, see
You can delete a collection from the database by using the

Dropping a collection from your database permanently deletes all
documents and all indexes within that collection.
Drop a collection only if the data in it is no longer needed.

argument.value: Dropping a Collection Deletes All Data in the Collection

children.value: You can control how the driver routes read operations by setting a

.
You can also control options for how the driver waits for acknowledgment of
read and write operations on a replica set by setting a
By default, databases inherit these settings from the

instance,
and collections inherit them from the database. However, you can change these
settings on your database by using one of the following functions:
The following example shows how to change the read preference of a database by using the
You can change the read and write settings on your collections by using one of the following functions:
The following example shows how to change the read preference of a collection by using the
To see the types of available read preferences, see the

To learn more about the read and write settings, see the following guides in the
MongoDB Server manual:
In the MongoDB Server, you can apply key-value

to replica-set
members according to any criteria you choose. You can then use
those tags to target one or more members for a read operation.

By default, the C driver ignores tags
when choosing a member to read from. To instruct the C driver
to prefer certain tags, use the

function to set the
tags in an instance of
In the following code example, the tag set passed to the

function instructs the C driver to prefer reads from the
New York data center (

) and to fall back to the San Francisco data
center (

mongoc_read_prefs_t *read_prefs = mongoc_read_prefs_new (MONGOC_READ_SECONDARY_PREFERRED);
bson_t *tags = BCON_NEW ("DC", BCON_UTF8("ny"), "DC", BCON_UTF8("sf"));

If multiple replica-set members match the read preference and tag sets you specify,
the C driver reads from the nearest replica-set members, chosen according to
their ping time.

By default, the driver uses only those members whose ping times are within 15 milliseconds
of the nearest member for queries. To distribute reads between members with
higher latencies, include the
parameter in your connection string URI.
The following example connects to a MongoDB deployment running on
and specifies a local threshold of 35 milliseconds:

In the preceding example, the C driver distributes reads between matching members
within 35 milliseconds of the closest member's ping time.

To learn more about any of the functions discussed in this
guide, see the following API documentation:

options.description: Learn how to use the C Driver to run a database command.

children.value:
In this guide, you can learn how to run a database command with the
C driver. You can use database commands to perform a variety of
administrative and diagnostic tasks, such as fetching server statistics,
initializing a replica set, or running an aggregation pipeline.

The driver provides wrapper functions for many database commands. We recommend
using driver functions instead of executing database commands when possible.
To perform administrative tasks, use the

instead
of the C driver. Calling the

method inside the
shell is the preferred method to issue database commands, as it provides a
consistent interface between the shell and drivers.

argument.value: Prefer Driver Functions to Database Commands

children.value:
To run a database command, you must specify the command and any relevant
parameters in a BSON document, then pass this BSON document to a command
execution function. The C driver provides the following functions to run
database commands:

, which runs a specified command on the
server and stores the first document from the result in the

BSON
document. This function provides a simplified way to send a command directly
to the server.

, which runs a specified command on the
server and interprets

according to the MongoDB server version. This
function offers flexibilty by allowing additional options.
The following code shows how you can use the

command, which returns information about the current
member's role in the replica set, on a database:
For a full list of database commands and corresponding parameters, see the
You can specify optional command behavior for the

function. This function accepts a BSON
document for the
You can pass a BSON document that specifies the following options:

To learn more about a command and the options that it accepts, locate the
command and follow the link in the
The following code shows how to specify a

functions ignore the read preference
setting you might have set on your client. By default, these functions use
the

To specify a read preference other than the primary read preference, you must
explicity pass it as an argument. The following code demonstrates how to
specify a read preference and use it with the
For more information on read preference options, see

Each function returns either a BSON document or a cursor containing the response
from the database after the command runs. Each database command performs a
different function, so the response content can vary across commands. However,
every response contains documents with the following fields:

: Provides fields specific to the database command. For
example,
The following code shows how you can use the

command clones a collection as a capped
collection. Then, the

command gets the distinct values of a field
with a given filter and collation. The example outputs the following result:

For more information about the concepts in this guide, see the following
documentation:

In this guide, you can learn how to use the C driver to store
and interact with
Time series data is composed of the following components:

The following table describes sample situations for which you could store time
series data:

To create and interact with time series collections, you must be
connected to a deployment running MongoDB Server 5.0 or later.

argument.value: Server Version for Time Series Collections

children.value:
You can create a time series collection to store time series data.
To create a time series collection, pass the following parameters to the
The database in which to create the collection
The name of the new collection to create
The following example creates a time series collection named

To verify that you successfully created the time series collection, run
the
You can insert data into a time series collection by using the

functions and specifying the measurement, timestamp, and metadata
in each inserted document.
To learn more about inserting documents into a collection, see the
The following example inserts New York City temperature data into the
time series collection created in the
Create a Time Series Collection example
. Each document contains the following fields:
, which stores temperature measurements in degrees Fahrenheit
, which stores the time of the measurement collection

You can use the same syntax and conventions to query data stored in a time
series collection as you use when performing read or aggregation operations on
other collections. To learn more about these operations, see
the

To learn more about the concepts mentioned in this guide, see the
following MongoDB Server manual entries:
Create and Query a Time Series Collection
Set Granularity for Time Series Data
